translated: Birth Stories

analyzed: dasaka nipāta  catu dvāra vagga  catu dvāra jātaka
translated: Ten-&-One Collection🔽The Chapter on the Four Gates🔽The Birth Story of the Four Gates
This city has four gates,
a strong iron wall;
I am shut in and shut out,
what evil have I done?
All the gates are closed,
I am shut out like a bird;
What is the reason, spirit,
that I am struck down by the wheel?
Having received a hundred thousand,
and more than twenty,
I did not do🔽the words of my compassionate relatives.
I crossed the ocean, I went forth,
the ocean is not easy to cross;
From the four I went to the eight,
and from the eight to the sixteen.

analyzed: soḍasāhi ca bāttisa  atriccham cakkam āsadaḥ
translated: From the sixteen to the thirty-two,🔽I went to the thirty-three;
For a person who is struck down by desire,
the wheel turns on his head.
The upper roof is hard to fill,
desire goes its own way;
But those who follow it,
they carry the wheel.
Having taken many goods,
without considering the road;
For those who do not consider this,
they carry the wheel.
“Consider your deeds and your vast wealth,
Do not pursue desires that are harmful;
Listen to the words of the compassionate,
Do not transgress such a wheel.”
“For how long, O Yakkha,
will the wheel remain on my head?
For how many thousands of years,
tell me this, when asked.”
“You are very wise, O wise one,
O Mittavindaka, listen to me;
The wheel will not pierce your head,
you will not die, you will be released.”
The Catudvāra Jātaka is the first.
